keyTakeAways: Bolivia’s first conservative president in 20 years, Rodrigo Paz, won 54.5% of the vote in a runoff election, marking a significant shift from decades of leftist rule.

Paz pledged to rebuild relations with the United States, especially after years of antipathy under the Movement Toward Socialism (MAS) party, and emphasized cooperation in investment, security, and immigration.

Paz rejected an IMF bailout, citing public resentment against international financial institutions, but is negotiating with the Trump administration and other countries for fuel imports to stabilize supply and curb inflation.
A key policy proposal is to shift fuel subsidies from universal to targeted cash transfers to poor families, preserving fuel prices for transport workers while reducing fiscal strain.

Paz’s campaign partner Edman Lara, a former police officer known for anti-corruption TikTok videos, helped mobilize rural and working-class voters, signaling a populist appeal to former MAS supporters.
The new government faces pressure to balance economic reform with promises to Indigenous communities, who were historically marginalized under previous governments.
Despite winning the election, unrest persists, with protests erupting over allegations of fraud and distrust in electoral integrity, especially following Morales’ disputed 2019 re-election.
Paz and his team have approved a $3.5 billion loan and are working on a $600 million budget to balance the books within 60 days of inauguration.
Paz pledged to reform the judiciary and convene a summit to propose concrete changes, signaling a push to restore institutional integrity and reduce political influence.

The shift in Bolivia’s politics reflects a broader regional realignment in Latin America, with a move toward conservative and pro-market policies, contrasting with the socialist legacy of Evo Morales.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Rodrigo Paz, Bolivia’s first conservative president in 20 years, has won a decisive victory in a presidential runoff election, marking a dramatic shift from decades of leftist rule under the Movement Toward Socialism (MAS) party. Winning 54.5% of the vote, Paz has pledged to rebuild relations with the United States, especially with the Trump administration, and to address Bolivia’s severe economic crisis by rejecting an IMF bailout and securing fuel imports. He is implementing a targeted fuel subsidy reform, shifting universal support to direct cash transfers for the poor, while maintaining stable prices for transport workers. His campaign partner, Edman Lara, a former police officer with a viral social media presence, helped mobilize rural and working-class voters. The new government faces challenges, including maintaining trust among Indigenous communities, who were historically empowered under Evo Morales, and managing domestic unrest over allegations of electoral fraud. With a $3.5 billion loan already approved and efforts underway to secure another $600 million, Paz aims to stabilize the economy and restore public confidence in institutions through reforms, including judicial overhauls, before making broader economic promises.
title: Rodrigo Paz Wins Bolivian Presidential Runoff, Marking End of Leftist Rule and Beginning of Conservative Era
